awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:  Atomic Level Structural Dynamics in Catalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Catalysts help make chemical reactions go faster and their development impact areas such as energy, the environment, biotechnology, and drug design. The vision of this project is to harness computational tools from modern statistics and machine learning to perform data-driven discovery of new catalysts. To this end, a collaborative team is assembled with the complementary expertise in catalysts, materials science, biophysics, computational modelling, statistics, signal processing, and data science. How a reaction is accelerated depends on the dynamic changes in the structure and shape of a catalyst and its associated chemical reactants (a catalytic system). The goal of this project is to explore, describe, and quantify the dynamic structures of enzyme and nanoparticle catalysts at the atomic level. Recent advances in microscopy and spectroscopy now make it possible to measure with great detail dynamic changes in time and in dimensional space. This project combines recent advances in data science with these new experimental tools to extract features that describe the dynamic behaviour of catalytic systems. In addition, the project will enhance the development of educational infrastructure for data-intensive and interdisciplinary science, contribute to workforce development, promote gender equality in the sciences, and disseminate scientific knowledge. 

The guiding hypothesis of this research is that catalytic functionality cannot be fully understood without describing the atomic-level structural changes triggered by the molecular interactions of reactants with the catalyst. This hypothesis is tested by utilizing experimental datasets obtained from electron microscopy and single-molecule fluorescence resonance energy-transfer spectroscopy to explore structural dynamics in nanoparticles and enzymes. A data-analysis workflow, which integrates denoising, dimensionality reduction, clustering, and dynamic Markovian modelling, enables descriptions and classifications of the complex dynamical evolutions in spatiotemporally resolved measurements. The research develops and applies advanced methodologies to process noisy, high-dimensional data - a crucial bottleneck for the analysis of dynamic systems. The information extracted from experimental data guides the computational sampling of the conformational space of proteins and nanoparticles within a statistical physics framework, using supercomputer technology. This information facilitates the development of physical models that probe phenomena that are currently experimentally inaccessible, such as picosecond nuclear motions, as well as protein conformational changes and their coupling with chemical events. The transformative impact is to better understand catalysis by establishing a link between dynamic system response and catalytic functionality. The computational approaches developed through this project have the potential to be generally applied to many fundamental problems in materials science and structural biology where dynamic behaviours are important.

This project is part of the National Science Foundation's Harnessing the Data Revolution (HDR) Big Idea activity, and is jointly supported by the HDR and the Division of Chemistry within the NSF Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Heterogeneous catalysis is an important approach to regulate and control chemical reactions in which an initial set of reactant molecules is converted into a final set of product molecules. It is estimated that 90% of all manufactured products involve catalytic processes somewhere in their production chain, and such products have considerable impact in energy generation and storage, healthcare (pharmaceuticals), agriculture, transportation, and the environment. Nanoparticle surfaces often serve as catalysts since they can regulate surface chemistry. The arrangements of the atoms in the nanoparticle, the so-called atomic structure, is believed to control catalysis but the fundamental processes taking place are not well understood.

To observe the atomic structure of a catalytic nanoparticle, powerful electron microscopes can be used. The high spatial resolution available in modern electron microscopes allows us to directly see the atoms in the catalytic nanoparticle. Some electron microscopes are equipped with small chemical reactors so that the atoms can be observed during a catalytic reaction. The electron detectors on state-of-the-art electron microscopes can generate very large quantities of data in a short period of time. A key question for the current project was to determine if the application of newly emerging techniques from data science, such as artificial intelligence, can help to elucidate what the atoms in the nanoparticle are doing under reaction conditions? Success would provide new tools to improve our fundamental understanding of catalytic processes at the atomic level.

It is very likely that during some catalytic reactions, the atomic structure of a nanoparticle may be dynamic and undergo changes. Migration of surface atoms is one mechanism by which the nanoparticle structure can change during a reaction. The modern cameras on electron microscopes can record atomic movies at speeds of up to 1000 frames per second. Unfortunately, the intensity of the electron beam that would be required to yield a clear image of the atomic structure in 1 millisecond (10-3s) would destroy most materials. If we reduce the intensity of the beam, the resulting images are very grainy and noisy and difficult to interpret.

During the project, several data science techniques were developed to address this problem. One approach that was explored involved a technique called denoising. If we have a movie composed of hundreds or thousands of frames, it may be possible to remove some of the noise and restore some of the information. We worked with our collaborators at the University of New York to develop new approaches to denoise based on artificial intelligence. Figure 1 is an example which shows a series of 5 consecutive frames from an atomic resolution movie of an environmental catalyst consisting of platinum (Pt) particles on a ceria (CeO2) support.  The catalyst was exposed to carbon monoxide and the movie was recorded at 75 frames per second so each frame corresponds to an exposure time of close to one hundredth of a second (0.01s). The upper set of images is the raw unprocessed data direct from the electron camera. The images are extremely noisy, and it is very difficult to discern any information about the atomic level structural dynamics. The lower row is the same set of frames after being denoised with artificial intelligence (specifically a convolutional neural network). The denoised images show the atomic columns in the Pt as white dots (white arrow). In some frames the white dots turn into streaks showing that the atoms are moving on the particle surface. This illustrates the power of artificial intelligence to reveal new information about the behavior of nanoparticle systems that was not previously accessible. This will ultimately deepen our understanding of dynamic processes taking place in materials impacting not only catalysis but many other technologies.

The project provided educational opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students from diverse backgrounds and underrepresented groups to learn about a wide range of disciplines due to the highly collaborative nature of the team. Through working group meetings, everyone was exposed to the domain areas of data science, nanoparticles, electron microscopy and concepts in catalysis.  The grant has provided partial support for 3 Ph.D. students, one undergraduate and a postdoctoral fellow. They have interacted with the students and postdocs at New York University and Cornell University and have gain experience applying convolutional neural networks and topological analysis techniques to electron microscopy data.
